3133.54.text:
No, because Switzerland has free trade agreements
with many countries in the rest of the world --

3142.56.text: We’re told we need to be in the EU for trade,

3146.40.text:
but Swiss exports per head are five times
higher than ours –

3150.44.text:
in fact, they’re about the most successful
exporting nation in the world.

3156.04.text: Then we’re told we need to be in the EU for jobs.

3159.24.text: We have a very high labour market participation --

3162.40.text: 83% of all people of working age work.

3166.10.text: That's much higher than the rest of Europe.

3170.60.text:
Switzerland has one of the lowest
unemployment rates in the world,

3174.42.text: lower than any country in the EU.

3182.26.text:
Don't be fooled by the mountains,
the cows and the cuckoo clocks

3191.54.text:
You might have heard
of Nestlé and Novartis and Roche.

3194.58.text:
the mining firm Glencore, Liebherr Cranes,
the high-tech engineering firm ABB,

3199.78.text: and of course every posh watch firm you can think of,

3202.52.text:
from Rolex and Omega and Tag Heuer,
to Patek Philippe and Zenith and Breitling.

3212.34.text: Just look at the most valuable companies in Europe:

3214.88.text: Novartis, Roche, Nestlé... they're all Swiss.

3218.70.text: Yup, Europe's biggest companies aren't even in the EU.

3224.82.text: Zurich is also one of the world's largest financial centres,

3228.10.text: despite having a population of less than 2 million,

3230.82.text: with global firms like UBS and Credit Suisse.

3236.48.text:
Per million of inhabitants, Switzerland has
more multinationals than, I think, all other countries.

3242.76.text:
No surprise, then, that Switzerland
is about the richest country in the world,

3246.82.text: with a GDP per head around twice as high as ours.

3251.16.text:
To make the point that if we left the EU, we’d be just like
another Switzerland, I think is totally bizarre.

3257.62.text: It is one of the most prosperous countries in the world.

3262.22.text:
Switzerland doesn’t just do a bit better than us;
it does fantastically better than us.

3268.08.text: Needless to say, the Swiss are better paid than us,

3270.54.text:
with the average wages, again,
around twice as high as ours.

3273.90.text:
What's more,
there is far greater income equality here.

3278.76.text:
Labour incomes are about
as equally distributed as in Scandinavia.

3283.92.text:
If you think high tax rates lead to equality,
look at Switzerland.

3287.52.text:
They have far lower tax rates than we do,
but very high levels of income equality.

3294.84.text:
So, without the EU’s help,
the Swiss seem to be scraping along just fine.

3299.90.text:
But how do we account
for Switzerland's truly staggering success?

3307.00.text:
I have come to the offices of the Swiss magazine
Die Weltwoche, or ''The World this Week''.

3313.74.text: The reason why Switzerland is successful economically

3318.00.text:
is that Switzerland
is not a member of the European Union.

3322.02.text:
In the EU, it’s politicians and bureaucrats
determining what the people have got to do.

3326.44.text: I mean, it’s a top-down system in the EU,

3329.60.text:
and Switzerland is, I would say,
is the epitome of a bottom-up system.

3337.20.text:
Switzerland is the perfect opposite
of the European Union’s crumbling model.

3342.14.text: Switzerland is a kind of super-democracy:

3345.20.text: far more democratic than Britain. let alone the EU.

3348.70.text:
Switzerland has one of the oldest constitutions
in the world, and it's one of the most democratic.

3353.52.text:
It’s not up to the Prime Minister whether
a referendum should be held – it’s up to the people.

3357.84.text:
You get 50,000 signatures,
and they have to hold one.

3361.06.text: The people in Switzerland decide everything.

3363.76.text: It's very different from the elite conception of politics,

3368.18.text: where an ''enlightened elite'' decides and knows better.

3371.94.text:
Here, the people know better,
and <i>politicians</i> have to conform.

3374.96.text:
Why is the Swiss state successful?
Because our politicians are forced

3379.92.text:
to fulfill the interests of the people.
The key to their success

3383.84.text:
is the fact that their class of bureaucrats and
politicians, if you will, is kept on a much tighter rein,

3388.82.text: a much greater control by the public.

3391.28.text:
You simply cannot get away with the kind
of grandiose plans that you find, say, in France.

3396.12.text:
In Switzerland, the Swiss public
simply will not tolerate that.

3400.88.text:
The Swiss economy ranks
as one of the least regulated in the world,

3404.88.text:
and according to the EU itself, Swiss industry
is also Europe’s most innovative.

3409.84.text:
Too much regulation stifles innovation,
limits creativity,

3414.00.text:
and so we think this should be
the foremost endeavour of politicians:

3419.00.text: to eliminate regulations and not to create them.

3423.10.text:
Switzerland is one of the least regulated
economies in the world,

3426.80.text:
and it's also one of the richest
countries in the world.

3432.34.text:
Do it like the Swiss –- have some arrangements
with Europe, but be independent and look to the world.

3439.70.text: Ah, being like Switzerland... that sounds good.

3445.36.text: To trade with Europe, won’t we need a trade deal?

3448.88.text:
No, there's so much nonsense talked
about trade agreements.

3451.64.text:
The EU is a trade deal,
and it’s very bad for us.

3465.42.text:
There's an old-fashioned view among politicians
that trade is something that politicians organise –-

3473.16.text:
Trade was all about
the great and the good from one country

3477.01.text:
signing a treaty with
the great and the good of another country.

3480.98.text: But real life is starting to leave that behind.

3486.32.text: I’ve headed back to South Shields to visit John Mills,

3489.84.text: one of the Labour Party’s biggest donors.

3492.34.text:
His company, JML, has hundreds of products
manufactured for them in countries all around the world,

3498.38.text:
and exports thousands of container-loads of goods
every year to every corner of the planet.

3507.26.text:
Well, we export
to about 85 countries at the last count –-

3510.66.text:
the majority of these countries
are not in the European Union --

3514.52.text:
but it’s actually no more difficult for us to sell
to the United States or to Australia or even China

3520.60.text: than it is to sell to the EU.

3524.48.text:
The idea that you have to be in the European Union
to trade with the European Union is a total absurdity.

3532.28.text:
Wander into any shop in Britain
and you’ll find goods from all over the world –-

3537.26.text:
cameras and TVs from Japan,
computers and phones from America --

3542.20.text: but we have no trade deals with these countries.

3545.60.text:
You don't need a trade deal with a country
to be able to trade with it.

3548.88.text:
If you go shopping, what do you do? Well, you buy
Chinese goods, you buy Korean goods, you buy American goods,

3554.70.text:
and yet none of those countries
is part of the European Union.

3557.64.text:
China doesn’t have a trade deal with the European
Union, nor does the United States, nor does India.

3564.36.text:
Trade involves having a product or a service
which other people are prepared to buy

3568.90.text: at whatever price you can produce it for.

3571.72.text: Though we don't need a trade deal to deal with Europe,

3574.76.text:
it’s highly likely <i>they</i> will want one,
for one simple reason:

3579.10.text:
The EU is desperate to keep its goods
flowing into the UK.

3583.06.text:
You go outside, you count –- don’t take my word for it –-
go count the number of Audis, BMWs, Mercedes, Volkswagens.

3592.98.text: You'll find it's over 30% of our market.

3595.40.text:
The Germans biggest industry needs us
to the tune of 16 billion plus every year.

3604.14.text:
We are actually the biggest market
for the rest of the European Union --

3609.50.text:
We are not a supplicant; we need a bit
of self-belief and a bit of self-confidence.

3615.70.text:
Even though we're EU members,
since the turn of the century,

3619.26.text:
the proportion of British trade with the EU
has been in steep decline,

3623.26.text:
while trade with the rest of the world
has been rising sharply.

3627.40.text:
There's no trade deal at the moment with China;
the EU does not have one.

3631.44.text:
But if you look at Anglo-Chinese trade
over the last ten years, say,

3635.12.text:
that has been growing several
times faster than Anglo-EU trade,

3639.70.text: where, of course, there is a trade deal.

3642.14.text:
Our percentage of trade with the EU
is falling virtually by the minute,

3646.56.text:
I mean, it’s tumbling even
as we conduct this interview.

3649.68.text:
Every single year that goes by, the percentage
of British overseas business that is done <i>outside the EU</i>

3655.00.text:
grows at double the rate
of the business we do <i>inside the EU</i>.

3659.08.text: They need us more than we need them.

3662.52.text:
Ah, but what if the EU proposes a trade deal
which forces on us open borders,

3667.94.text: and other stuff we don't like?

3671.22.text:
If a proposed trade deal is unacceptable to us,
whether it’s the EU or anybody else,

3679.30.text:
It’s true that British companies who export
to the EU will have to comply with EU regulations,

3685.02.text:
but it’s also true that EU companies wanting
to export to Britain will have to comply with ours.

3690.96.text:
Germans who export to America
must abide by American regulations,

3694.42.text:
likewise for American exporters to China,
and Chinese exporters to Brazil, and Brazil to the EU;

3701.36.text:
every exporting company in the world has to comply
with the laws of the place they’re exporting to.

3710.64.text:
One of the arguments
put by the ''In'' crowd –- the ''Remainers'' --

3715.50.text:
is ''Oh, well, you know, it takes a long time
for Europe to come up with a free trade agreement --

3720.26.text:
it’s taken 9 years to come up
with a free trade agreement with Canada –-

3723.24.text: well, that's a very good reason to leave.

3725.86.text:
In the globalised 21st century,
you don't need a trade deal to trade,

3732.52.text:
The question is: are we more likely to have bigger
and better trade deals inside the EU, or outside?

3740.80.text:
Let’s add up the GDP of all the countries
that have trade deals with the EU:

3745.02.text: it comes to five trillion pounds.

3751.66.text:
And what about tiny Singapore? They’ve got trade
deals worth seven times as much as the EU’s.

3758.68.text:
Chile, population 8 million:
its got 50 trillion… Unbelievable!

3763.44.text:
But let’s cheat: let’s add to the EU pile
the value of its own internal market,

3767.88.text:
as if it had a trade deal with itself.
It’s still rubbish!

3771.82.text:
You can’t throw a shipping container without hitting
a country with better trade deals that the EU.

3778.64.text:
In fact if you’re trying to avoid trade deals,
joining the EU is probably the best thing you can do.

3783.80.text:
The EU has got no trade agreement
with China or India or Russia or the United States.

3789.72.text:
I mean, it’s staggering
that they haven’t managed to achieve that.

3792.36.text:
Of Britain’s top 10 non-EU trading partners,
the EU has trade agreements in place with only two.

3801.92.text:
As far as trade deals go, being part of the EU
cuts you off from the rest of the world.

3809.30.text:
Our history is a trading, buccaneering history –-
back to Drake and beyond,

3814.38.text: and that's what we're good at.

3816.56.text:
At the moment, our hands are shackled
by being in the European Union.

3820.98.text:
We’ve got a much, much better opportunity,
really, for striking good trade deals

3824.58.text: if we’re outside the EU than if we’re inside.

3827.46.text:
If we left the European Union, we could
very quickly establish free trade deals

3831.86.text: with the most dynamic parts of the world economy.

3835.92.text: Today, Europe doesn't look like the future.

3838.26.text:
The future consists of nations
in Asia and America and Africa.

3842.76.text:
Getting stuck in Fortress Europe
is the worst thing that could happen to us.

3847.32.text:
The idea that we have to stay in the EU
for our prosperity is wrong-headed.

3851.82.text:
Why do we need to attach ourselves to the one
part of the world that is doing really badly?

3857.10.text:
Within Europe we know what our future’s going to be
to some extent –- it’s going to be pretty stagnant,

3861.88.text: while the rest of the world roars ahead.

3865.80.text:
We have huge scope, huge scope
for creating vast numbers of new jobs.

3871.84.text:
Being obsessed with just this corner of the world
is being a ''little European''.

3877.22.text:
Outside Europe, we could have prosperity
on a level that we can’t even imagine now.

3883.44.text:
Escaping Fortress Europe
could be a new start for Britain;

3887.34.text:
a return at last to the global commercial
and trading giant we were in the 19th century.

3893.86.text:
If we embrace free trade and escape
the stultifying restrictions of EU over-regulation,

3899.54.text:
there’s the potential
for an extraordinary economic renaissance.

3904.02.text:
Britain is a great country. I think our economy
is poised for much greater things.

3908.88.text: I think in the last two or three decades,

3911.60.text: something really interesting's happened in this country.

3917.18.text:
young people now want to go it alone, they want to run
their own businesses, they want to be self-employed.

3922.68.text:
They don’t want to work for these big multinationals
any more; they want to build their own multinationals.

3928.92.text:
But to restore this level of prosperity,
we must take back the right to govern ourselves.

3935.84.text:
We’re being asked to trade in our freedom –-
and look what we’re offered in return.

3943.90.text: It is about bread and circuses, isn’t it?

3946.06.text: Bread and circuses for the little people.

3948.34.text:
The political class say to us, ''You needn’t worry
about sovereignty or any of that stuff.

3953.28.text:
''You’re going to get better mobile phone rates,
and that’s the good news.

3957.46.text: ''And you're going to get slightly cheaper holidays.

3960.96.text: ''And those are the things that really matter to you, aren't they?

3962.96.text: ''Because you're one of the little people.''

3964.98.text:
I mean, would you really trade in your national identity
for cheaper mobile phone calls when you're abroad?

3971.32.text:
They’re treating us like natives in the 18th century,
when Captain Cook lands on the shore

3976.38.text:
and he starts handing out these...
these beads and trinkets,

3978.80.text:
and we’re going to be happy with that,
and we’re going to sell them our country for them.

3983.26.text:
It just shows utter contempt
for what they think people are like,

3986.60.text:
because they really do believe
that these little trinkets are going to buy us off.

3992.74.text: In the referendum, we will be asked to choose.

3996.20.text:
Do we want to be governed by an organisation
which we don’t understand,

4000.34.text: run by people we don’t know and haven’t elected,

4003.62.text:
who have the power to impose on us
laws that we haven’t debated,

4007.30.text:
and have little or no chance
of blocking or repealing?

4011.70.text:
We need to regain the right
for British people to make British laws.

4015.64.text:
If people believe that the best way
to strengthen the United Kingdom

4019.74.text: is to hand over every year more money, and more power,

4023.28.text: to an unaccountable bureaucratic elite in Brussels,

4025.80.text:
then what they should do
is campaign to stay in the European Union.

4028.96.text: It comes down to the essential issue,

4031.74.text:
the working man and woman of this country
against people who think,

4036.78.text:
''We have a better plan and a better mind than you,
and if you don’t like it, what are you going to do?''

4045.10.text: And the answer is, we're going to vote:

4052.64.text:
There are a number of issues
where I believe that we should be leaving.

4057.46.text:
This is people vs. the establishment –-
people vs. the elite.

4061.30.text:
I just hope that the mass of people
who may not go around being interviewed much,

4066.12.text:
may never get a look in
on any of the media or television,

4069.58.text:
come June the 23rd will be out there saying,
''This is our chance to get our own back.

4076.02.text: ''Give us back control of our own country.''

4079.24.text:
With general elections, it doesn’t really matter
who you vote for, Conservative or Labour,

4082.74.text:
because you know that in four years' time
you can change your mind.

4086.04.text:
This time, you can't change your mind.
This time, it's for keeps.

4090.40.text:
This referendum is the most important political act
that has happened in my lifetime –-

4098.42.text:
this is about our future, our freedom, our democracy –-
our right to govern ourselves.

4105.36.text:
What really matters is that you should have
the power to remove the people who govern you.

4110.44.text:
The reason why the suffragettes
went to all that trouble to get the vote

4114.72.text:
was because they wanted to, they themselves,
be treated as grownups and decide their own destiny.

4120.40.text:
If I was told I would be stewing grass
to feed my own family in five years' time

4125.46.text:
if we left the European Union –-
I would still do it!

4128.74.text: It's time to regain our freedom and independence,

4132.50.text: the right to decide <i>ourselves</i> how we live our lives.

4135.96.text:
There is a lot at stake here.
What we want is democracy.

4139.96.text: We the people should determine our own destiny.

4143.58.text: We have the capacity to shape our own futures.

4146.86.text: So my question is: What price freedom?
